required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Arterial Line Patency in ICU Bound COVID-19 Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Risk Factors Affected the Duration of Arterial Line Patency in ICU Bound COVID-19 Patients

brief_summary.textblock: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-Cov-2) overwhelmed the health care system and ICU admission was maximized with increased work load of ICU physicians. Invasive line procedures are inserted with a dedicated team to ensure safe and perfect performance. Frequent requests for arterial line insertion were observed during the second wave follow up of COVID-19 bound patients. High rates of thrombosis were found in those critically ill patients which was associated with thrombotic complications. Many factors are contributed for reduction of arterial line patency, including morbidities of patients, technique of insertion, and criteria of the operating health care skilled personnel. In response of our ICU management committee to increase incidence of thrombosis and pulmonary embolic events in patients with COVID-19 admitted to ICU in the second wave of the epidemic, they recommended the use of systemic anti coagulation of ICU admitted patients since 21 March 2021.

detailed_description.textblock:
1. Introduction / Background
ICU admission for patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been increased and it was observed that this epidemic is associated with high rates of thrombosis which augmented its consequences for those critically ill patients [1], [2].
During peak admission of patients with COVID-19 to ICU, we initiated a dedicated invasive procedure team from anesthetists to provide a multidisciplinary, safe service for invasive vascular procedures, moreover, endotracheal intubations and rapid response team (RRT) for quick assessment of deteriorating patients in ward which in need for ICU admission which was reported before at USA institute [3].
Hemodynamic monitoring and management in patients undergoing high risk surgery used the invasive vascular access particularly in ICU admitted patients [4].
Different methods used to reduce the incidence of arterial line failure as the use of heparinized solutions [5].
Their main aim was to augment the median patency duration of 5-10 days [6]. The arterial line occlusion was reported when it was inserted for longer than 2-3 days [7]. A temporary arterial obstruction occurs frequently as a common complication [8].
During COVID crisis, we noticed increased requests for arterial line insertions either in newly admitted or already present ICU patients. The repeated insertions of arterial lines may challenge the ICU provider as well as it increases risk of ischemic thrombosis and infectious events in the patient's limbs. However, there were few reports about risk factors associated with arterial lines obstructions in patients with COVID -19 admitted to ICU [9] .
In response of our ICU management committee to increase incidence of thrombosis and pulmonary embolic events in patients with COVID-19 admitted to ICU in the second wave of this epidemic, they recommended the use of systemic anti coagulation of ICU admitted patients since 21 March 2021.
Aim of this observational study to investigate the impact of systemic anti coagulation on the arterial line patency and incidence of arterial line failure comparing patients before implementation of systemic anti coagulation versus patients after its implementation.
Secondary outcome will identify risk factors which associated with impaired arterial line patency in both groups.

primary_outcome.measure: Primary Objective: is to investigate the impact of systemic anti coagulation on the arterial line patency and incidence of arterial line failure comparing patients
primary_outcome.description: Primary Objective: is to investigate the impact of systemic anti coagulation on the arterial line patency and incidence of arterial line failure comparing patients before implementation of systemic anti coagulation protocol versus patients after its implementation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Secondary Objective: is to identify risk factors which associated with impaired arterial line patency in both groups.
secondary_outcome.description: Secondary Objective: is to identify risk factors which associated with impaired arterial line patency in both groups.

intervention.description: arterial line inserted for invasice mointroing and sampling

study_pop.textblock: Consecutive ICU patients at HMGH Hospital; Hamad Medical Corporation with continuous invasive monitoring will be enrolled if they met following eligibility criteria: peripheral artery cannulation with a suitable arterial cannula and a functional arterial line established after insertion.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Consecutive ICU patients at HMGH Hospital; Hamad Medical Corporation with continuous invasive monitoring will be enrolled if they met following eligibility criteria: peripheral artery cannulation with a suitable arterial cannula and a functional arterial line established after insertion.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Other pateints with COVID-19 NOT ICU bound
